screens.headline: Why did your CSP lose 40% while mine made 20%?
screens.text: Stock selection is 70% of CSP success. Sell puts on the wrong stock and you'll be holding bags forever. In 7 minutes, you'll learn the screening criteria that separate winning trades from disasters.

screens.headline: The Golden Rule: Only Sell Puts on Stocks You WANT to Own
screens.text: This is the most important rule in CSP trading. If you wouldn't buy 100 shares of this stock at this price TODAY with cash, don't sell a put on it. Getting assigned should be a HAPPY outcome, not a disaster. If assignment scares you, you picked the wrong stock.

cards.definition: Strong business, good financials, you'd hold 5+ years if needed
cards.example: ‚úÖ AAPL, MSFT, GOOGL | ‚ùå Meme stocks, penny stocks

cards.definition: Higher IV = bigger premiums (more income per put sold)
cards.example: Look for IV Rank >50 or premiums >2% monthly

cards.definition: Tight bid-ask spread, high volume (easy to enter/exit)
Stock has technical support near your strike (less likely to crash)
cards.example: Stock $380, support at $360, sell $360 put (support = floor)

cards.definition: Not at all-time highs, not overpriced bubble stock
cards.example: ‚úÖ P/E 20-30, healthy range | ‚ùå P/E 200, priced for perfection

screens.question: Stock A: Blue chip, IV 25%, premium $2. Stock B: Meme stock, IV 90%, premium $8. Which for CSPs?
options: Stock B if you want to own it, Stock A if you don't
Both are fine - more premium is always better
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! The $8 premium is tempting but meaningless if you don't want to own that meme stock at the strike. If you LOVE the meme stock and believe in it, then $8 premium is great. If not, stick with the safer $2 on Stock A. Match picks to YOUR conviction!
screens.explanation_wrong: More premium doesn't mean better trade! Stock B pays 4x more because it's 4x riskier. Would you want to own 100 shares of that meme stock if assigned? If no, don't sell the put - no matter how juicy the premium!

screens.question: You're screening: NVDA (tech, volatile, IV 60%), KO (stable, boring, IV 20%). You have $40k for CSPs. Which stock?
options: KO - safer, won't crash as hard
Depends on your risk tolerance and conviction
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Aggressive investor who believes in NVDA? Sell NVDA puts for 3-4% monthly. Conservative investor who wants steady income? KO for 1-2% monthly but safer. Or split 50/50. No 'right' answer - match to YOUR goals and conviction!
screens.explanation_wrong: There's no universal 'best' stock for CSPs. It depends on: (1) Your risk tolerance, (2) Which stock you want to own, (3) Your income vs safety preferences. Be honest about your style!

screens.headline: Think of it like dating
screens.text: CSP = you're getting paid to go on dates (collect premium) while waiting to marry someone (buy stock). Don't date people you'd NEVER marry just because they pay for expensive dinners (high premium). Only date people you could see yourself with long-term (quality stocks you'd own). If you get 'married' (assigned), you should be happy - not trapped in a bad relationship!

reveal_sections.label: Expensive dinners = High premium (tempting but risky)
Long-term compatibility = Quality stocks you'd hold 5+ years

cards.back: 1. You'd want to OWN this stock. 2. Quality company (would hold 5+ years). 3. Liquid options. Everything else is negotiable!
Meme stocks you don't believe in, leveraged ETFs, penny stocks, stocks with bad earnings, anything you wouldn't hold if assigned.
Start with 2-3 stocks you know well. Don't over-diversify (spreads thin). Focus on quality over quantity.
